Logistic Fixed Effect Model

Source: vignettes/Logis-FE.Rmd
Logis-FE.Rmd

Estimation

The computational tools designed for general-purpose model fitting in generalized linear models, such as those relying on Newton-Raphson and Fisher scoring, fall short in meeting the computational demands as the number of providers increases. This limitation arises due to the substantial escalation in computational cost when incorporating thousands of provider effects into the parameter space. Consequently, the inversion of the Fisher information matrix becomes a computationally burdensome task, posing a significant challenge even for workstations specifically engineered for such purposes. To address this issue, the SerBIN algorithm, proposed by Wu et al.Â (2022), leverages the block structure of the Fisher information matrix. This innovative approach substantially reduces the time complexity associated with inverting the high-dimensional matrix, particularly when confronted with the presence of thousands of provider effects.

Consider a binary outcome as an illustration. Let mm represent the total number of providers, nin_i denote the number of subjects from provider ii(i=1,â€¦,m)(i = 1, \dots, m), and N:=âˆ‘i=1mniN := \sum_{i = 1}^m n_i signify the total number of records. For subject jj(j=1,â€¦,ni)(j = 1, \dots, n_i) from provider ii, let YijY_{ij} be the outcome variable, and let ZijZ_{ij} constitute the vector of risk factors. The likelihood function can then be formulated as follows: l(ğ›„,ğ›ƒ)âˆâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni{Yijâ‹…(Î³i+Zijğ›ƒ)âˆ’log(1+eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ)},l(\boldsymbol{\gamma}, \boldsymbol{\beta}) \propto \sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i}\{Y_{ij} \cdot (\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}) - log(1 + e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}})\}, and the corresponding score function can be expressed as: U(Î³i)=âˆ‘j=1ni{Yijâˆ’eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ1+eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ}U(\gamma_i) = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{Y_{ij} - \frac{e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}\}U(Î²p)=âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni{Zijpâ‹…(Yijâˆ’eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ1+eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ)}.U(\beta_p) = \sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{Z_{ijp} \cdot (Y_{ij} - \frac{e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}})\}. In the current context, the information matrix can be visualized as a 2Ã—22 \times 2 block matrix, expressed as: I(ğ›„,ğ›ƒ)=(I(ğ›„)I(ğ›„,ğ›ƒ)I(ğ›ƒ,ğ›„)I(ğ›ƒ))â‰¡(I11I12I21I22). I(\boldsymbol{\gamma}, \boldsymbol{\beta}) = \begin{pmatrix} I(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) & I(\boldsymbol{\gamma}, \boldsymbol{\beta}) \\ I(\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{\gamma}) & I(\boldsymbol{\beta}) \end{pmatrix} \equiv \begin{pmatrix} I_{11} & I_{12} \\ I_{21} & I_{22} \end{pmatrix}. It is important to note that the I(ğ›„)I(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) block is â€œlargeâ€ but diagonal. Consequently, we can compute Iâˆ’1(ğ›„,ğ›ƒ)I^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\gamma}, \boldsymbol{\beta}) as follows: Iâˆ’1(ğ›„,ğ›ƒ)=(I11âˆ’1+J1TSâˆ’1J1âˆ’J2Tâˆ’J2Sâˆ’1),I^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\gamma}, \boldsymbol{\beta}) = \begin{pmatrix} I_{11}^{-1} + {J_1}^{T} S^{-1} J_1 & - {J_2}^{T} \\ - {J_2} & S^{-1} \end{pmatrix}, where J1=I21I11âˆ’1J_1 = I_{21}{I_{11}}^{-1}, S=I22âˆ’J1I12S = I_{22} - J_1 I_{12}, and J2=Sâˆ’1J1J_2 = S^{-1}J_1.

The bottleneck in SerBIN lies in computing I22I_{22} (i.e., I(ğ›ƒ)I(\boldsymbol{\beta})) when the sample size nn is exceptionally large. However, each element of I22I_{22} can be individually computed, allowing for parallel computing to enhance computational efficiency: I(ğ›ƒ)r,c=âŸ¨Z(r),Z(c)âˆ˜â„™âŸ©,I(\boldsymbol{\beta})_{r,c} = \langle Z^{(r)}, Z^{(c)} \circ \mathbb{P} \rangle, where âŸ¨a,bâŸ©\langle a, b \rangle denotes the inner product of aa and bb (i.e., aTba^T b), âˆ˜\circ represents the Hadamard product (element-wise product), and â„™=eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ(1+eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ)2\mathbb{P} = \frac{e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}{(1 + e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}})^2}. Itâ€™s worth noting that I(ğ›ƒ)I(\boldsymbol{\beta}) is symmetric, so thereâ€™s a need to calculate only the upper triangular entries.

(To avoid instability for ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma} estimation in our code, we restrict the ğ›„Ì‚[l]{\hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}}^{[l]} estimates to a specific range during each iteration. The default range is ğ›„Ì‚med[lâˆ’1]Â±10{\hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}_{med}}^{[l-1]} \pm 10.)

Standardized Ratio/Rate

In addition to the outputs for covariate coefficients and provider effects, users can use the SR_output() function by specifying the standardization method (â€œdirectâ€ or â€œindirectâ€) for computing provider-level ratio/rate, where:

  • Indirect standardization ratio (ISR) is computed as follows:

ISRi=OiEi,ISR_i = \frac{O_i}{E_i}, where Oi=âˆ‘j=1niYijO_i = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} Y_{ij} is the observed number of events for provider ii, and EiE_i is the â€œexpectedâ€ number of events for provider ii, calculated as Ei=âˆ‘j=1nieÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒ1+eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒE_i = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}. Here, Î³0\gamma_0 represents the â€œpopulation averageâ€, defaulting to the median value of all Î³Ì‚i\hat{\gamma}_iâ€™s.

In the context of indirect standardization, the interpretation of EiE_i can be expressed as follows: â€œWhat would be the expected number of events of provider ii, if provider ii performs at the national average level?â€ (see He and Schaubel. (2014) and Jones, Ohlssen, and Sprigelhalter. (2008) ). An ISRi>1ISR_i >1 indicates that provider iiâ€™s observed event rate is higher than expected based on the national average.

  • Direct standardization ratio (DSR) is determined by the formula:

DSRk=E(k)O,{DSR}_k = \frac{E^{(k)}}{O}, where O=âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niYijO = \sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} Y_{ij}, and E(k)=âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1nieÎ³Ì‚k+Zijğ›ƒ1+eÎ³Ì‚k+Zijğ›ƒE^{(k)} = \sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{\hat{\gamma}_k + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}{1 + e^{\hat{\gamma}_k + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}.

In the context of direct standardization, the understanding of E(k)E^{(k)} can be articulated as follows: â€œWhat would be the expected number of total events, if all providers performs as provider kk?â€.

If Î³Ì‚k=âˆ\hat{\gamma}_k = \infty, E(k)=NE^{(k)} = N, resulting in DSRk=NO{DSR}_{k} = \frac{N}{O}; and if Î³Ì‚k=âˆ’âˆ\hat{\gamma}_k = -\infty, E(k)=0E^{(k)} = 0, leading to DSRk=0{DSR}_{k} = 0.

Users also have the option to request the function to generate a â€œstandardized rateâ€, which is computed as ISRiISR_i or DSRkÃ—ONDSR_k \times \frac{O}{N}.

(Please be aware that the computed â€œindirect rateâ€ might surpass 100%. To prevent any confusion, we manually constrain the result within the range of 0% to 100%.)

Hypothesis Testing

The test_fe() function provides hypothesis testing outcomes to assist users in identifying outlier providers with extreme outcomes. By default, we use the median of all estimated provider effects as the null value (i.e.Â H0:Î³i=Î³Ì‚medH_0: \gamma_i = \hat{\gamma}_{med}). Users can choose from various testing methods, including â€œexact.poisbinomâ€ (default), â€œexact.bootstrap,â€ â€œscore,â€ and â€œwaldâ€:

  • â€œexact.poisbinomâ€: Assume Yij|Zijâˆ¼Bernoulli(pij)Y_{ij}|Z_{ij} \sim Bernoulli(p_{ij}). Since within the provider ii, pij=eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒ1+eÎ³i+Zijğ›ƒp_{ij} = \frac{e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_i + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}} varies, Oi|Zi=âˆ‘j=1niYijO_i | Z_i = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i}Y_{ij} will follow the Poisson-binomial distribution. We then calculate the probability of â€œgetting a more extreme number of OiO_i, if H0:Î³i=Î³0H_0: \gamma_i = \gamma_0 is trueâ€ based on the Poisson-binomial distribution.

  • â€œexact.bootstrapâ€: The test is conducted in the following steps: (1) Repeat B=B = 10,000 times (default): Simulate Yij(b)âˆ¼Bernoulli(eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒ1+eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒ){Y_{ij}}^{(b)} \sim Bernoulli(\frac{e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}}}), and calculate Yi(b)=âˆ‘j=1niYij(b){Y_{i}}^{(b)} = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} {Y_{ij}}^{(b)}. (2) Calculate the frequency that Yi(b){Y_{i}}^{(b)} is more extreme than OiO_i. (3) calculate the pâˆ’p-value. (â€œExact Bootstrapâ€ is consistent to â€œExact Poisson-binomialâ€)

  • â€œwaldâ€: When H0:Î³i=Î³0H_0: \gamma_i = \gamma_0 is true, Î³Ì‚iâˆ’Î³0se(Î³Ì‚i)âˆ¼N(0,1)\frac{\hat{\gamma}_i - \gamma_0}{se(\hat{\gamma}_i)} \sim N(0, 1). The se(Î³Ì‚i)se(\hat{\gamma}_i) can be computed using the formula mentioned earlier (I11âˆ’1+J1TSâˆ’1J1I_{11}^{-1} + {J_1}^{T} S^{-1} J_1) but with only diagonal elements. (The â€œWald testâ€ is not valid for outlying providers (i.e. Î³Ì‚i=Â±âˆ\hat{\gamma}_i = \pm \infty). â€œError messageâ€ is added in the code to inform users.)

  • â€œscoreâ€: In the standard score test procedure, the first step involves computing the â€œrestricted MLEâ€ of ğ›ƒÌ‚(i)\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{(i)}. Subsequently, calculate U(Î³i)|Î³i=Î³0=âˆ‘j=1ni{Yijâˆ’eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚(i)1+eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚(i)}U(\gamma_i)|_{\gamma_i = \gamma_0} = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{Y_{ij} - \frac{e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{(i)}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{(i)}}}\}, and I(Î³i)|Î³i=Î³0=âˆ‘j=1ni{eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚(i)(1+eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚(i))2}I(\gamma_i)|_{\gamma_i = \gamma_0} = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{\frac{e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{(i)}}}{(1 + e^{\gamma_0 + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{(i)}})^2}\}. Under H0H_0, U(Î³i)|Î³i=Î³0I(Î³i)|Î³i=Î³0âˆ¼N(0,1)\frac{U(\gamma_i)|_{\gamma_i = \gamma_0}}{\sqrt{I(\gamma_i)|_{\gamma_i = \gamma_0}}} \sim N(0, 1). However, given the potentially high dimensionality of Î³\gamma, re-fitting the new restricted model for each provider effect test could be challenging. Therefore, instead of using ğ›ƒÌ‚(i)\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{(i)}, we solely employ the ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} estimated by the full model.

Confidence Interval

The choices for calculating confidence intervals of Î³i\gamma_i include the following methods:

  • â€œexactâ€: Based on the Poisson binomial distribution of Oi|ZiO_i|Z_i. We numerically find the range of Î³0\gamma_0 such that Pexactâ‰¥0.05P_{exact} \geq 0.05, which involves locating the roots of an equation.

  • â€œwaldâ€: Directly convert Î³Ì‚iÂ±1.96Ã—se(Î³Ì‚i)\hat{\gamma}_i \pm 1.96 \times se(\hat{\gamma}_i), which is invalid for outlying providers.

  • â€œscoreâ€: Find the range of Î³0\gamma_0 such that U(Î³i)|Î³i=Î³0I(Î³i)|Î³i=Î³0âˆˆ(âˆ’1.96,1.96)\frac{U(\gamma_i)|_{\gamma_i = \gamma_0}}{\sqrt{I(\gamma_i)|_{\gamma_i = \gamma_0}}} \in (-1.96, 1.96).

We can also derive the confidence interval for ISRiISR_i or DSRiDSR_i based on the confidence interval for Î³i\gamma_i.

  • ISRiISR_i: Given that the score equation provides Oi=âˆ‘j=1nieÎ³Ì‚i+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚1+eÎ³Ì‚i+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚O_i = \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{\hat{\gamma}_i + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{\hat{\gamma}_i + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}, the CI of ISRiISR_i can be calculated as:

CIISRi=(âˆ‘j=1nieÎ³i,L+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚1+eÎ³i,L+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚Ei,âˆ‘j=1nieÎ³i,U+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚1+eÎ³i,U+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚Ei).CI_{ISR_i} = (\frac{\sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{\gamma_{i,L} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_{i,L} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}}{E_i}, \frac{\sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{\gamma_{i,U} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{\gamma_{i,U} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}}{E_i}). Here, Î³i,L\gamma_{i,L} and Î³i,U\gamma_{i,U} are the lower and upper bounds of Î³i\gamma_i. (If CI(Î³i)CI(\gamma_i) covers Î³0\gamma_0, then CIISRiCI_{ISR_i} will cover 1.)

  • DSRkDSR_k: Considering DSR0=âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1nieÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚1+eÎ³0+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚âˆ‘i=1mOi.DSR_{0} = \frac{\sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{{\gamma}_0 + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{{\gamma}_0 + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}}{\sum_{i = 1}^m O_i}. The CI of DSRkDSR_k can be calculated as:

CIDSRk=(âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1nieÎ³k,L+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚1+eÎ³k,L+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚âˆ‘i=1mOi,âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1nieÎ³k,U+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚1+eÎ³k,U+Zijğ›ƒÌ‚âˆ‘i=1mOi).CI_{DSR_k} = (\frac{\sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{{\gamma}_{k,L} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{{\gamma}_{k,L} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}}{\sum_{i = 1}^m O_i}, \frac{\sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \frac{e^{{\gamma}_{k,U} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{{\gamma}_{k,U} + Z_{ij}\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}}{\sum_{i = 1}^m O_i}). Similarly, Î³k,L\gamma_{k,L} and Î³k,U\gamma_{k,U} are the lower and upper bounds of Î³k\gamma_k. (If CI(Î³k)CI(\gamma_k) covers Î³0\gamma_0, then CIDSRkCI_{DSR_k} will cover DSRkDSR_k.)
